awd_titl_txt: Classification of Methods for Bayesian Inverse Problems Governed by Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
Inverse problems emerge in all areas of science, engineering, technology, and medicine. They provide a systematic and rigorous way to extract knowledge and insight from observational data. When this data corresponds to observations of natural or engineered systems that can be described by mathematical models, the properties and structure of the inverse problem depend on the properties of these models, which commonly involve partial differential equations (PDEs).  It is crucial that efficient inverse problem solution methods exploit these properties. This is in particular the case when the inversion parameters are high (or infinite) dimensional, when the mathematical models are given by PDEs, and when one is interested in quantifying the uncertainty in the parameters, as is important in many applications.

This project will systematically study properties and develop algorithms for three inverse problems that are representative of a wide class of Bayesian inverse problems governed by PDEs: (1) a parabolic inverse problem with spatially (and temporally) well-separated parameter and observation locations, (2) an elliptic Stokes flow problem for which a rich set of measurement data are available and the locations corresponding to parameters and observations are not well-separated, and (3) a hyperbolic problem with sparse point measurements. The PI will study these problems theoretically, develop and classify structure-exploiting methods to approximate their solutions, and implement these methods in an open-source software library.  All three prototype problems have important and societally relevant real-world, large-scale analogues. Thus, any algorithmic or theoretical findings obtained for the three model problems will have immediate benefit for these grand challenge inverse problems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed at the study of practical approaches to approximate the solution of Bayesian inverse problems governed by partial differential equations (PDEs). The accuracy of approximations of the solution, namely the posterior distribution of the parameters, depends on several factors, including properties of the underlying PDEs and how uncertain parameters enter in these equations. The project studied problems governed by elliptic, hyperbolic and parabolic PDEs and various approximations of the posterior distribution, including maximum a posterior (MAP) point estimation, Laplace approximations combined with compression of the covariance operator, and Markov chain Monte Carlo sampling methods. We find that there are no generic approximation methods that always work, but that what works best depends on the prior and noise distributions, and on the degree of nonlinearity in the map from parameters to observations.  Based on these approximations, as part of the project we also studied optimal data acquisition by formulating optimal experimental design problems,i.e., asking the question where and how one should collect observation data in order to optimally inform uncertain parameters.
The PI taught two graduate courses at NYU, which were related to this project, namely "Computational Inverse Problems" and "Finite Elements". These courses were well-attended by graduate students in Mathematics,Computer Science and Engineering. He also co-organized two summer schools on topics closely related to the project. One was the 2-week Gene Golub SIAM summer school in Colorado in June 2018 with the title:Inverse Problems: Systematic Integration of Data with Models under Uncertainty. This school was attended by a diverse group of 45 graduate students.
